Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Thermodynamics of Magma Mixing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Molten rock (magma) forms at tens to hundreds of kilometers below Earth's surface. These magmas can ascend, and each year on Earth, about 30 cubic kilometers erupts or stalls, much of it within a few thousand meters of the surface. Transport and storage of magma in the crust (uppermost layer of the solid Earth) is associated with the formation of many strategically- and economically-important mineral resources including gold, platinum, chromium, diamonds and other gemstones and represents a source of untapped green energy called geothermal heat. The research carried out in this study advances infrastructural knowledge of how magmas evolve chemically and thermally through interactions with crust and as they cool, mix, and eventually solidify. Because all magmas initially contain small amounts of dissolved water and carbon dioxide, as magma cools and crystallizes, it often becomes a bubbly mixture containing high-pressure fugitive gas that can produce explosive eruptions, thereby posing risks to humans, property and ecosystems. This research seeks to better understand these phenomena based on the latest results from condensed matter physics, fluid mechanics, and chemical thermodynamics, all in the context of complex system behavior.

Magma emplaced in the crust is a classic example of a complex, open system where magmas and crustal host rock exchange material and energy. The thermochemical evolution of magma subject to this exchange is responsible for much of the compositional diversity observed on Earth. This research applies chemical thermodynamics to predict from first-principles the products of magma crystallization and to relate these products to the amount of geothermal energy that flows to the environment. Open system magmatic behavior that emphasizes the consequences of complete blending of two distinct magma batches (a process called magma mixing) is modeled using two mass and energy constrained computational tools: an exploratory model that utilizes simplified mixing thermodynamics and a more complex model, called the Magma Chamber Simulator, that employs state of the art thermodynamics. Simulations using these codes will generate a theoretical magma mixing taxonomy that will classify thermal and chemical characteristics of mixing end-members and products. This taxonomy will be tested by applying it to carefully chosen volcanic and plutonic rock suites that show clear evidence of magma mixing. Analysis of mixed magma products will define mass and thermal consequences of mixing that can be used to refine models of eruption, magma emplacement, and mass and energy exchange from deeper to shallower levels in Earth. Both computer codes will be enhanced to better capture the open-system characteristics identified by these studies, and public distribution of these computer resources to the earth and planetary sciences community will augment computational analysis of magma formation and evolution. The ultimate end product of this research will be enhanced understanding of the transport, storage, and eruption of molten rock, an integral part of the planetary plate tectonic recycling process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magma (molten rock) that erupts at volcanoes typically forms from melting of rocks deep in the Earth. As magma travels toward Earth’s surface, it can stall in magma chambers (storage zones) where an array of processes changes magma. The primary processes that cause changes to the composition and eruptability of magmas are formation of crystals, mixing of two distinct magmas, and incorporation of melted rock and/or crystals from the magma chamber walls, which are typically a different composition than the magma in the magma chamber.

This grant funded enhancements to a computer code, called the Magma Chamber Simulator, that uses mathematical equations and the laws of thermodynamics to simulate changes that magmas experience in magma chambers. This computer code was used by students at Central Washington University and other universities to study how magmas, erupted at various volcanoes on Earth, changed prior to eruption. Two volcanoes, Lassen Peak (California USA) and Parinacota (Northern Chile), were studied to better understand how mixing of new magma into an existing chamber may have influenced eruption. Computational modeling showed that mixing produced new magmatic products and may have changed the characteristics of the magma enough to prompt eruption. The modeling suggests different timescales between mixing and eruption; in the case of Lassen, it appears some cooling of the magma had to occur, which took some time, whereas at Parinacota, mixing appears to have occurred without much cooling, potentially suggesting a shorter timeframe from mixing to eruption. These timing differences may have implications for volcanic monitoring. A study of Mt Etna (Italy) suggests that a possible eruption catalyst was incorporation of carbon dioxide-rich rocks that surround the magma chamber, which increased the concentration of gasses in the magma. Like a coke bottle that is opened, pressure is released as magma moves toward Earth’s surface. This causes gas bubbles to form, a process that may cause an eruption. A separate study provided information about the processes that form magmas that erupt during flood basalt events. These eruptions are aptly called flood basalts because the eruptions flood the Earth’s surface with hundreds of thousands or more cubic kilometers of lava. A study of a flood basalt terrane in southeastern Oregon used the Magma Chamber Simulator to show that in the associated magma chambers, previously formed crystals are recycled into new magmas during magma mixing. This process yields growth of some very large crystals, some of which are mined for jewelry. Crystal recycling and magma mixing may be important at other flood basalt locations.

The use of the Magma Chamber Simulator allows scientists who study magmas to test scientific hypotheses about how magmas change by employing the important principles of mass and energy conservation. The use of the Magma Chamber Simulator also has societal relevance. The research outlined above as well as other studies help enhance volcanologists’ understanding of how, when, and why volcanoes erupt.

The Magma Chamber Simulator was developed to be a community tool. Access to the computer program, documentation and training videos, are available at https://mcs.geol.ucsb.edu/. The Magma Chamber Simulator “team,” which consists of students and professors from several universities world-wide, held a number of training workshops to help students and researchers integrate computer modelling tools into their own research programs. The training and availability of the Magma Chamber Simulator allow researchers at all levels to use the computer code to address questions about the origin and evolution of magmas and also address questions of societal importance, such as what processes in magma chambers might initiate eruption? When combined with other avenues of study about eruption catalysts, computer tools can enhance scientists’ understanding of volcanoes, and thus hopefully improve volcanic hazard assessment and mitigation.

This grant had additional impact in that it partially supported research for 3 BS and 4 MS degree students at Central Washington University. Several of these students are first-generation college students, and several are underrepresented in the geosciences. Six of the seven students are female. These students developed independent research projects that allowed them to enhance career skills. Most of the students presented their work at a scientific conference, which allowed them to interact with other scientists and required them to enhance their science communication skills. Some presentations were also given to the general public in Washington State. All of these students are still active in the geosciences: 3 have geoscience jobs and 4 students (all women) are pursuing PhD degrees in geology.

As a part of this grant, professors and students at Central Washington University developed stronger collaborations with students and professors at other universities (e.g., Santa Barbara (California, USA) and Helsinki (Finland)). This international working group allowed the participants to be exposed to different cultures and ways of thinking about geology.
